title: China wins the race against the US in aluminum recycling output, capacity and expansion
summary: Mysteel reports that China has more than doubled its secondary (recycled) aluminum output since 2010 and now accounts for roughly 38–40% of global recycled aluminum production; the piece notes significant new secondary projects in 2024 that added over 2.05 million tonnes of planned capacity and brought total secondary capacity to about 17.62 million tonnes[1]. The article contrasts China’s rapid expansion of recycled aluminum with the US, where secondary production growth has been modest and the economy has become secondary-dominant rather than primary-focused[1].

title: Aluminum - Price - Chart - Historical Data - News
summary: Trading Economics summarizes recent aluminum market moves and notes that China — the world’s top producer — is expected to approach its 45-million-ton annual cap, limiting room for further production growth and affecting global supply expectations[2]. The page also highlights recent supply disruptions and planned smelter setbacks (for example in Indonesia) that are influencing prices and capacity outlooks[2].

title: Australia's biggest aluminium smelter gets promise of cheaper renewable power from feds and state
summary: RenewEconomy reports that the Australian federal and NSW state governments have agreed support measures to keep the Tomago aluminium smelter operating amid high energy costs, securing more than 1,000 jobs and protecting production of up to 590,000 tonnes per year from the plant[3]. The article emphasizes that electricity is a major cost (about 40% of operating costs) for Tomago and that the support will underwrite new renewable generation, storage and transmission to reduce smelter power costs[3].

title: Affected by transportation disruptions in Xinjiang, social inventory — SMM Spot Aluminium
summary: Shanghai Metals Market (SMM) commentary (carried on metal.com) notes that recent transportation disruptions in Xinjiang have constrained aluminum movements and that newly announced capacity takes time to translate into production, limiting output growth in December[5]. The piece indicates near-term supply-side tightness due to logistical issues despite new capacity coming online more slowly than expected[5].

title: Meadow pushes aluminum circularity with US production partnership
summary: Packaging Insights covers Meadow’s collaboration with a U.S. production partner to scale aluminum circularity and onshoring of aluminum packaging production in the U.S., driven by rising extended producer responsibility (EPR) laws and demand for recycled or circular aluminum packaging[6]. The report discusses implications for expanding U.S. production capacity for recycled aluminum in packaging supply chains[6].

title: Aluminum melted with Annular Fresnel solar at over 700°C
summary: SolarPACES reports an engineering demonstration that used Annular Fresnel solar concentrators to melt aluminum at temperatures over 700°C, showing potential for low‑carbon, localized aluminum recycling and small-scale production using solar thermal technology[4]. Trials achieved multiple melt/pour cycles and validated the approach as a scalable, lower‑cost route for recycling aluminum in regions with high direct normal irradiance[4].

title: Aluminum Market Trends (collection)
summary: S&P Global Energy’s Aluminum Market Trends collection summarizes key drivers affecting the U.S. aluminum industry in 2025, including debates over import tariffs on Canadian aluminum and other policy, supply and capacity dynamics shaping U.S. production and investment decisions[7]. The collection provides research and event coverage relevant to capacity, tariffs and domestic production trends[7].

title: Trojan Horse
summary: FDD’s analysis highlights China’s dominant role in primary aluminum production (nearly 60% of global primary supply) and discusses strategic vulnerabilities tied to global dependence on Chinese aluminum capacity for defense‑relevant manufacturing[9]. The piece links production concentration to geopolitical and industrial-policy risks rather than immediate daily capacity changes[9].

title: Aluminum's Impact on Sustainable Development Goals
summary: Aluminum drives sustainable development through recycling innovation, energy efficiency, and economic growth, particularly in electric vehicles with 15-20% range extension. Technology priorities include AI in sorting for better recycling efficiency and closed-loop manufacturing. Market projections show growth in sustainable aluminum demand through 2030 with investment opportunities in recycling and renewable integration.

title: Aluminium Giants Hit Major Milestone with Low-Carbon Production
summary: Elysis, a joint venture of Alcoa and Rio Tinto, achieved a breakthrough by installing carbon-free inert anode technology in a 450-kA cell, scaling up from pilots used in Apple products and Audi wheels. The technology uses inert materials to avoid CO2 emissions and features a vertical design for longer anode life and potential cost reductions. This positions aluminum production to compete in a carbon-conscious economy amid global decarbonization efforts.

title: Lightweighting for a Sustainable Future: Unlocking the Aluminum Advantage for Automakers
summary: Aluminum enables lighter vehicles, reducing energy use by up to 45% in body structures compared to steel, lowering emissions for both ICE and EV models while minimizing battery needs and mining impacts. Its infinite recyclability uses only 5% of primary production energy, cutting GHG emissions by 95% and supporting circular economies. Versatility simplifies manufacturing, reduces parts, and streamlines supply chains for sustainable mobility.

title: Aluminum melted with Annular Fresnel solar at over 700°C
summary: Fraunhofer team in Chile demonstrated low-cost annular Fresnel solar mirrors melting aluminum at over 700°C for recycling, achieving 1.71 kg daily melts in tests from Nov 2024-May 2025. The system supports domestic recycling of exported scrap, producing zero-carbon 'green aluminum' for demand from multinationals in food packaging. Validated for scaling in high-DNI regions to meet policy-driven metal recycling goals.

title: Aluminum beverage can recycling rate hit 75% globally: report
summary: Global aluminum beverage can recycling reached 75% in 2023, advancing circular economy goals per a COP30 report. The International Aluminium Institute targets 80% by 2030 and near-total by 2050, as announced at COP28. Industry leaders highlight this as a major step for sustainability.

title: Aluminum stabilizes high-nickel cathodes, curbing rapid capacity loss in EV batteries
summary: Aluminum doping stabilizes high-nickel cathodes in EV batteries by preventing structural distortion and capacity degradation at the atomic level. This innovation boosts energy density, lifespan, and safety by mitigating thermal runaway risks. The research expands design options for next-generation high-performance batteries.

title: Norway Begins Production of Recycled Aluminum License Plates
summary: Norway launched production of license plates from recycled aluminum in December 2025, marking a sustainability milestone. The project promotes circular economy practices in public infrastructure.

title: Steel - Price - Chart - Historical Data - News
summary: Steel prices fell to 3045 CNY/T on December 12, 2025, down 0.03% from the previous day, amid demand uncertainties in China. Steel rebar futures dropped toward CNY 3,040 per ton, the lowest in a month, despite Beijing's reaffirmation of broad economic support measures. Over the past month, prices have fallen 0.10%, and are down 7.36% year-over-year.

title: HRC Steel - Price - Chart - Historical Data - News
summary: HRC Steel fell to 906.07 USD/T on December 12, 2025, down 0.10% from the previous day. Over the past month, prices have risen 5.97%, and are up 34.37% compared to the same time last year. The update reflects trading on a contract for difference tracking the benchmark market.

title: Global Iron and Steel Prices and News
summary: SteelRadar provides daily updates on global iron and steel prices, including Shanghai Futures Rebar terms showing no change on December 12, 2025. Indices cover various futures contracts for rebar and other steel products across regions like Turkey, China, Europe, and North America. The platform aggregates prices, news, and analyses for the iron and steel industry.

title: [SMM High-grade NPI] Prices Edge Up Slowly, Yet Market Transactions Remain Sluggish
summary: High-grade NPI prices edged up slowly on December 11 amid weak fundamentals in December's off-season. The average price of 10-12% high-grade NPI saw a rebound, but market transactions remained sluggish. This reflects ongoing challenges in the nickel pig iron segment tied to steel production.

title: Canada Says Tighter Limits on Steel Imports to Take Effect on Dec. 26
summary: Canada's finance department announced that new limits on steel imports will take effect on December 26 to support the domestic steel sector amid U.S. tariffs. The measures reduce imports from non-free-trade countries like China, Turkey, and Brazil to 20% of 2024 levels before a 50% tariff applies, and limit FTA countries (excluding U.S. and Mexico) to 75% of 2024 levels. This follows Algoma Steel's plan to cut 1,000 jobs due to unsustainable blast furnace production.

title: Thyssenkrupp pauses steel production at two sites citing Asian pressure
summary: Thyssenkrupp Steel Europe will pause production at sites in Gelsenkirchen, Germany, and Isbergues, France, from mid-December until year-end due to low-cost Asian imports causing capacity underutilization. The French site will run at 50% capacity from January for at least four months. The company seeks faster EU trade protections amid ongoing challenges like high energy costs and plans to cut 11,000 jobs and reduce capacity to 9 million tons annually by 2030.

title: Beijing Moves to Rein in Steel Exports With New Licensing Rule
summary: China's Ministry of Commerce and General Administration of Customs announced export licensing requirements for most steel products starting January 1, 2026, to curb surging low-priced shipments and illicit trade. Steel exports reached 110 million tons in 2024, forecasted at 110-130 million tons in 2025, with first-10-months 2025 exports at 97.7 million tons and prices down 8.7% to $695.4/ton. The measure covers crude iron, billets, coils, plates, pipes, and scrap, amid rising global trade remedy investigations against Chinese steel.

title: New Delhi Supports Tata Steel Indo–Sweden Partnership For Cleaner Industry, Innovation
summary: The article reports that New Delhi has extended support to Tata Steel under the Indo–Sweden Industry Transition Partnership to advance low‑carbon steel technologies and circular processes, including projects that recover metals from steel slag and convert residues into low‑carbon cement additives, presented at COP30 and launched at the Swedish Embassy in New Delhi.[1]

title: Green steel innovation: Tata Steel to establish HIsarna technology plant in Jamshedpur; Aims for sustainable production with 1 MTPA capacity
summary: Tata Steel has approved engineering and regulatory work to build a ~1 million tonnes per annum HIsarna demonstration plant in Jamshedpur, deploying a low‑carbon ironmaking route that can use lower‑grade ore and eliminate coke while integrating slag reuse to cut emissions.[2]

title: Latest News & Updates (industry perspectives on decarbonisation, hydrogen pilots, circularity)
summary: ResponsibleSteel's news update highlights industry progress and challenges in steel decarbonisation: hydrogen‑based pilots, increased integration of renewable electricity, and a stronger focus on circular scrap‑based production, while noting barriers such as green hydrogen cost and infrastructure constraints.[3]

title: Green Steel Tracker — recent entries and analysis on low‑carbon investments and technology needs
summary: LeadIT's Green Steel Tracker continues to log public announcements of low‑carbon steel investments and publishes analyses (including hydrogen and renewable electricity demand for EU transition), tracking industry commitments and gaps in net‑zero targets among major producers.[4]

title: How technology is reshaping metal recycling
summary: The piece explains how digitalisation, sensors and advanced analytics are improving metal recycling quality and efficiency for the steel supply chain, citing technologies such as laser‑induced plasma spectroscopy for material composition analysis and control systems that reduce downtime and energy use.[5]

title: Weyerhaeuser and Aymium to rapidly scale biocarbon market (metallurgical‑grade biocarbon for iron & steel)
summary: Weyerhaeuser and Aymium announced plans to scale production of metallurgical‑grade biocarbon as a drop‑in replacement for coal and coke in iron and steel production, targeting up to 1.5 million tonnes annually at full scale to reduce carbon intensity of metallurgical processes.[6]

title: Comex copper ends the week 1.83% lower at $5.2835 — Data Talk
summary: Front‑month Comex copper for December delivery fell 9.85 cents per pound (1.83%) for the week, closing at $5.2835, marking the largest one‑week percentage decline since early November and snapping a two‑week winning streak. The report notes copper remains well above its 52‑week low and up roughly 32% year‑on‑year, while intraday volatility included a larger single‑day drop that was the biggest since late October[4].

title: Copper eases after nearing $12,000, set for 3rd straight weekly jump
summary: Copper prices eased after earlier touching near $12,000 per tonne but remained on track for a third consecutive weekly gain, pressured by demand uncertainty out of top consumer China even as Chinese policymakers signalled measured economic support for 2026. The piece highlights the tension between strong recent rallies and short‑term profit‑taking or demand concerns that have driven intraday swings[7].

title: Copper — Price, Chart, Historical Data, News
summary: Trading Economics reports copper fell to $5.28 per pound on December 12, 2025 (down ~2.4% from the prior day) after reaching multi‑month highs earlier; the site also notes copper is up roughly 27–32% year‑on‑year and reached an all‑time high in July 2025. The page synthesizes price moves, recent drivers including Chinese stimulus expectations and a U.S. Fed rate cut, and includes linked short market updates on rallies and pullbacks[1].

title: Tight supply and AI demand drive copper prices higher
summary: The article attributes recent copper strength to tightening physical supply and rising demand tied to AI and energy‑transition trends, reporting prices around $11,952 per metric tonne as of December 12, 2025. It frames the rally as supported by structural demand growth (EVs, renewables, AI infrastructure) alongside inventory movements that have tightened availability[3].

title: LME metal inventories update — Copper inventories reported (December 13)
summary: Metal.com’s inventory update shows LME copper stock movements on December 13, 2025, signaling ongoing shifts in exchange inventories that market participants watch for clues on near‑term physical tightness. The update provides transaction price ranges and inventory figures that help explain short‑term price volatility and regional flows affecting LME balances[8].

title: Capital demands soar for new copper supply
summary: Capital demands for new copper supply projects have significantly increased, with 13 out of 22 analyzed projects postponing start dates and facing higher development costs. Capstone Copper's Santo Domingo project in Chile saw the largest capex jump of $910 million (55%), boosting annual copper production to 68,500 metric tons. Barrick's Reko Diq in Pakistan remains a key project with 377,000 metric tons annual output planned for 2028.

title: Anglo American posts 9% drop in copper output in first nine months
summary: Anglo American reported a 9% decline in copper production to 526,000 metric tons in the first nine months compared to 575,000 tons last year, though Q3 output slightly rose to 183,500 tons. The company maintained its 2025 guidance of 690,000-750,000 tons amid restructuring and a proposed merger with Teck Resources. Production challenges persist despite raised iron ore outlook.

title: Copper upside building on tight supply
summary: Copper supply disruptions throughout the year are tightening the 2025 and 2026 market balance, with recent issues at Freeport contributing to the strain. These interruptions highlight ongoing challenges in maintaining production capacity amid rising demand. The article emphasizes building upside potential for copper prices due to constrained supply.

title: Copper Demand Surges as Clean Energy Rewrites Net Zero Goals
summary: Copper demand is surging due to clean energy needs, requiring 5x more copper than conventional systems for net zero goals. Mining companies are partnering with tech firms on innovations like autonomous equipment, advanced ore sorting, and real-time monitoring to boost production and sustainability. These advances aim to offset declining ore grades while meeting environmental commitments.

title: Metal Mania: Reuters on Copper, Tin, Zinc, Lithium, Cobalt and More
summary: Recycling and technological innovation are key to addressing growing metal demand, particularly for copper. In China, increased scrap copper from aging infrastructure could offset shortages through 'urban mining.' This reduces reliance on primary mining and supports supply dynamics.

title: Nickel - Price - Chart - Historical Data - News
summary: Nickel rose to 14,620 USD/T on December 12, 2025, up 0.07% from the previous day, though down 2.27% over the past month and 7.91% year-over-year. Nickel futures fell toward $14,600 per tonne amid persistent oversupply and elevated LME stockpiles exceeding 250,000 tonnes. The market bounced after testing a four-year low, with UK futures at $14,800 per tonne.

title: [December 13 Morning Meeting Summary] Refined Nickel: Spot Premiums Update, Nickel Futures Rise
summary: Domestic refined nickel closed at 117,080 yuan/mt on Friday, up 1.99% week-over-week. LME nickel prices rebounded significantly to $14,850/mt on Friday. Spot premiums and futures showed upward movement in the morning meeting.

title: Nickel Prices Had Slightly Increased This Week
summary: Shanghai nickel warehouse receipts inventory stood at 30,564 tons as of December 13th, up 985 tons week-over-week. Nickel prices showed a slight increase amid inventory buildup. Market trends indicate modest upward pressure despite ongoing supply dynamics.

title: The Market In Numbers - 13 Dec 2025
summary: Nickel price per pound recorded at 6.6005, down 0.90% as of December 13, 2025. This reflects broader metals market movements, with nickel under slight downward pressure. Part of daily metals and minerals pricing update.

title: Nickel Industries (ASX: NIC) Soars with Quota Approval: Is It a Buy?
summary: Indonesian authorities approved an increase to Nickel Industries' 2025 nickel ore sales quota from 9 million to 10.5 million wet metric tonnes. This allows resumption of deliveries from the Hengjaya Mine to the Indonesia Morowali Industrial Park, supported by a five-year AMDAL permit and in-pit tailings system. The approval addresses ongoing oversupply pressures amid rapid capacity expansion.

title: North American Niobium and Critical Minerals Corp. Announces Closing of Oversubscribed $1.96m Flow-Through Financing
summary: North American Niobium and Critical Minerals Corp. closed an oversubscribed $1.96 million flow-through financing. This follows a news release on December 4, 2025, providing funds likely for critical minerals exploration including nickel-related activities. The financing supports the company's development in the critical minerals sector.

title: North American Niobium and Critical Minerals Corp. Announces Closing of Oversubscribed $1.96m Flow-Through Financing
summary: North American Niobium and Critical Minerals Corp. announced the closing of its oversubscribed $1.96 million flow-through financing. The update references a prior release from December 4, 2025. Funds will advance critical minerals projects, potentially including nickel production capacities.

title: Re-energising the nickel industry through sustainable battery production
summary: Queensland Pacific Metals is developing the TECH Project to become a leading supplier of high-grade, ethically derived nickel for EV batteries using the patented DNi Process™. The project will import nickel laterite ore from New Caledonia to a carbon-negative facility in Townsville, Australia, with offtake agreements from LG Energy Solution and POSCO. This supports sustainable production of critical battery metals amid the green energy transition.

title: ZincFive Wins Multiple Categories in the 2025 Power Technology Excellence Awards
summary: ZincFive has won awards in Innovation, Product Launch, Safety, and Environmental Excellence for its nickel-zinc (NiZn) battery technology. The NiZn batteries offer high power density, safety, and sustainability with 25-50% lower lifetime greenhouse gas emissions than lead-acid or lithium-ion alternatives. This recognition highlights advancements in cleaner power solutions for mission-critical and AI-intensive applications.

title: Aluminum stabilizes high-nickel cathodes, curbing rapid capacity loss in EV batteries
summary: Researchers have identified lattice structural distortion in high-nickel cathodes as the cause of rapid capacity loss in EV batteries, leading to oxygen holes that degrade performance. Substituting a small amount of nickel with aluminum suppresses these oxygen holes, stabilizing the structure and significantly enhancing battery lifespan and safety. This breakthrough offers a strategy to improve energy density and mitigate thermal runaway in next-generation batteries.

title: Tenaris hosts panel on nuclear energy and Italy's boilermaking future
summary: Tenaris hosted a panel discussion titled “Nuclear: the future of the Italian boilermaking industry” at Fondazione Dalmine in Italy, partnering with UCC. Experts from industry and institutions discussed nuclear energy's role in Europe’s energy transition and Italy’s manufacturing potential, including small modular reactors. Tenaris’s Italian mill recently obtained accreditation for nuclear materials under ASME III standards.

title: Tenaris Acquires isOplus Oil and Gas Division in $10M Deal Expands Pipe Coating Business
summary: Tenaris acquired the oil and gas division of isOplus for $10 million, gaining pre-insulated pipeline systems and anti-corrosion coatings in Europe. The unit has been rebranded as Tenaris Coating Italy, enabling coatings on line pipes at facilities in Italy, Mexico, Argentina, and Brazil. This strengthens Tenaris's offshore market offerings by reducing delivery times and costs.

title: Tenaris publishes new Environmental Product Declaration for seamless pipes
summary: Tenaris certified an Environmental Product Declaration (EPD) for its seamless steel pipes, based on 2022 data from seven mills including Dalmine in Italy. The EPD covers cradle-to-gate environmental performance, showing 79% recycled steel content and up to 74% recyclability at end-of-life. It complies with EN 15804+A2 and ISO 14025 standards, supporting transparency and decarbonization efforts.

title: Tenaris to supply OCTG, line pipe and coatings for Suriname's first offshore development
summary: TotalEnergies awarded Tenaris a contract for 47,000 tons of casing, tubing, and Rig Direct® services for the GranMorgu project off Suriname. Production of line pipe and coatings, including anticorrosion and thermal insulation, will occur at Tenaris facilities in Italy and Mexico under the One Line® model. This integrates Shawcor’s coatings to support the deepwater basin development.

title: Tenaris S A : Weekly Report (December 8, 2025 - December 12, 2025)
summary: Tenaris published its weekly share buyback report for December 8-12, 2025, detailing purchases like 497,790 shares on MTA at a weighted average price. As of December 12, the company holds 51,262,421 treasury shares, equal to 4.78% of issued capital, with plans to cancel them. The report is available on Tenaris's IR website.
